newsitem.title: GERMANY: REUTERS GERMAN ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST - AUG 11.
newsitem.headline: REUTERS GERMAN ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST - AUG 11.

text.p: REUTERS GERMAN ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST
News from Reuters and the German press on Advertising, Marketing, Media, the Internet, Brand-name Products and Consumer Trends
ADVERTISING & MARKETING:

BERLIN - Berlin-based advertising agency Dorland says it expects a 20 percent boost in turnover for 1997, propelled by publicity generated by its recent capture of Honda's German image account. "The Honda account has provided us with a lot of interesting inquiries from other companies," Dorland managing director Stefan Hansen says. (Reuters)
FRANKFURT - Auto rental company Sixt awards its media account to CIA in Duesseldorf. (Horizont)

KRONBERG - TMM-Turkmedia, a unit of media marketing company IP Deutschland, drops ad prices on its Turkish-language channel TRT International an average of 10 percent compared to this year's rates. Kanal D, another of the company's stations, raises ad prices 28 percent. (Reuters)
MEDIA & THE INTERNET:

BERLIN - ProSieben Media AG plans to buy majority shares in children's TV station Nickelodeon in Germany, the newspaper Welt am Sonntag reports. The agreement is to be signed in the next few days. Nickelodeon is 90-percent owned by U.S. company Viacom and Ravensburger Film + TV GmbH, with a 10-percent share. (Reuters)
BONN - Autobild, a car magazine, starts its own online offer on AOL. (Horizont)
BRAND-NAME PRODUCTS & MARKETS:

INGOLSTADT - Audi AG, the luxury carmaker, says pre-tax profits climbed 20.9 percent in the first half of this year to 489 million marks ($262.2 million), driven by strong foreign demand. Audi, the luxury car arm Volkswagen AG , says group sales increased 13.7 percent during the first half of the year to 10.6 billion marks -- an increase that analysts said came largely on the back of its mainstay A4 saloon. (Reuters)

BONN - Germany's traditional two-week summer sales period got mixed reviews from some of the country's major department stores as poor weather and worries about the economy weighed on sales in some regions. A survey of major retailers throughout the country showed that many stores in east Germany were not happy about the number of customers or the level of sales. (Reuters)

ZURICH - The top executive of General Motors Corp's international operations says the U.S. carmaker has been winning over managers at its European units for the group's ambitious global expansion plan. (Reuters)

MUNICH - Net profit at tyre-maker Continental AG grew by some 50 percent in the first half of 1997, Conti's management board chairman Hubertus von Gruenberg says. The group plans to increase sales to 20 billion marks within 10 years, and to increase net profits to 800 million marks. (Reuters)

FRANKFURT - German medical services group Fresenius Medical Care AG says that changes in U.S. legislation governing home health care could significantly boost its earnings in the U.S. A spokesman for the company says that Fresenius could earn approximately $60 million more per year from the legal change, but warned that accurate estimates were not yet available. (Reuters)
PEOPLE NEWS:
FRANKFURT - Joerg Tilmes is new chief executive at Kia Motors in Germany. (Horizont)
FRANKFURT - Mike Taylor is named chief executive of the German unit of Toys "R" Us. (Horizont)
